title: Here’s what’s happening next in Democrats’ impeachment inquiry into Trump
text:
Tom Brenner/Getty Images House Speaker Nancy Pelosi

With their impeachment inquiry opened, House Democrats are preparing to take a two-week break from Washington and return to their districts to hear from their constituents.

The prospect of removing President Donald Trump from office will almost certainly be a hot topic of discussion, as a new poll showed support for impeachment rising moderately among registered voters.

See: How support for impeachment is rising among Americans — in one chart.

House and Senate lawmakers are scheduled to return from recess on Oct. 15. But House Intelligence Committee members have reportedly been told to be prepared to return to Washington over the break. CNN reported it’s possible the committee could hear testimony from the whistleblower who filed a complaint alleging the White House tried to conceal the details of Trump’s call with the Ukrainian president.

Lawmakers say they could draft articles of impeachment over the Ukraine matter by the end of October, writes the New York Times.

Don’t miss: Complete MarketWatch coverage of the Trump impeachment inquiry

Trump has denied wrongdoing in the matter. The complaint alleges he sought to use the powers of his office to push President Volodymyr Zelensky to investigate former Vice President Joe Biden and his son.

Friday morning, Trump attacked House Intelligence Committee Chairman Adam Schiff, calling for the California Democrat’s resignation. Schiff has said some of his comments at a Thursday hearing about Trump’s July conversation with Zelensky were meant partly in parody.

“I am calling for him to immediately resign from Congress based on this fraud!” Trump tweeted.

The latest developments come at the end of a week that saw the release of the whistleblower complaint and a summary of a call between Trump and Zelensky. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi announced the impeachment inquiry on Tuesday.

Opinion: Five points every investor ought to consider about the Trump impeachment inquiry

Read: Faint hope that Congress will ride to rescue of slowing economy extinguished by impeachment push

A simple majority of the entire House is required for impeachment. If Trump were impeached by the House, a trial could be held in the Senate. With the Senate in Republican control under Majority Leader Mitch McConnell, however, such a case could be dismissed immediately.

U.S. stocks SPX, -0.53% DJIA, -0.26% were trading mixed Friday, heading for a second weekly loss, as investors monitored developments around U.S.-China trade talks and the impeachment drama.
